The Gift Cards they are talking about are an alternative to the old idea of book tokens and other gift vouchers that you can buy in shops, the difference being that they have a 'Credit Card Number' printed on them that can be used for internet transactions. They are fixed-value, one-off cards that can\'t be topped up and nor can you borrow money with them, and you don\'t need to supply any personal information when you buy them. After use they are disposable.

So, if a person can manage to scrounge up the equivalent of $15.00 in cash and has a convenience store near them that sells these Gift Cards, then they have the means to buy KSP without running any risk or offending any rules laid down by parents etc.

Keep in mind that that personal info is kept confidential by Squad. It is more for helping to prove you are you if a hiccup occurs in a transaction or with your game account. So it actually is to your benefit. The information that does not include a red asterisk is not required and therefore you do not have to fill in. The rest is information you give every day to friends and stores anyway and not so personal.

Anybody reading this thread who are under 18 and is looking for help on purchase, please make sure you get your parent\'s or guardian\'s assistance. Taking initiative and buying your own gift card to buy the game is commendable, but you can end up entering in info that might be better left off. I know I am sounding like an overprotective granddaddy here, but where your personal info and finances are concerned, it pays to be careful. It helps to learn from your elder\'s goofs.

I totally get this, in three ways.

First, Spearka is obviously young, and trying to honor his parents. Let\'s show some respect for that.

Second, the financial industry has earned our scorn. If someone doesn\'t want their child to use a credit card or PayPal, it absolutely makes sense; let\'s respect that too. In my opinion, suggesting Spearka use a MasterCard gift card is too close to circumventing his parents. The right thing to do would have been to suggest his parents process the transaction for him.

Third, not all of us enjoy the growing trend toward zero privacy. Yes, when I bought KSP I entered the required info. But I did so grudgingly, because I know how to protect myself, and as a boring old guy I\'m not much of a target. A minor is a target for certain people, and needs to be that much more cautious. Please, let\'s be respectful of people trying to protect their privacy.
